awd_titl_txt: EAGER: Theoretical Foundation for the Use of Approximations and Heuristics in Systems Engineering and Design
awd_abstract_narration:
In practice, engineers often rely on heuristics and approximations to arrive at good system designs efficiently and effectively.  Heuristics are rules of thumb that embody engineering experience.  When used appropriately, they save engineering time and effort without sacrificing the quality of the system being engineered.  However, the use of heuristics and approximations is poorly understood.  This EArly-concept Grant for Exploratory Research (EAGER) project will enable a fundamental understanding and development of design heuristics and associated processes, guiding researchers and practitioners in advancements and use of such heuristics, and ultimately, providing a formalized foundation to design science. The research will combine mathematical foundations, such as probability theory and decision theory, with empirical observations of students and experienced engineers to develop explanatory models for the use of heuristics and approximations.  The research will make strides in formalizing design heuristics from various disparate approaches, and recommend how and when heuristics are best used in design practice. In addition, it will lead to new insights regarding how to teach design better by clearly identifying the heuristic nature of design knowledge, and by coaching students to continually update their heuristics through the contextualization of the underlying foundations and through life-long learning.

Systems engineering and design currently lack a strong theoretical foundation, and, in particular, the community has struggled to bridge the gap between current practice and the normative, axiomatic, mathematical theories that underlie systems engineering and design.  To fill this gap in knowledge, the objective of this research is to enhance the scientific understanding of the use of approximations and heuristics in systems engineering and design. A normative theory will be derived for the use of approximations and heuristics by explicitly accounting for the value of the resources required to execute designer actions, starting from the von Neumann-Morgenstern axioms of decision theory. Heuristics found will be cataloged and analyzed by characterizing their value or 'validity.' The relationship between design heuristics and cognitive heuristics as studied in psychology will be considered, bridging the gap between descriptive and prescriptive theories, identifying gaps between the two, and deriving hypotheses regarding the improvement of design practice in situations in which the gap between normative theory and current practice appears to be large. This research will assist in enabling a fundamental understanding and development of design heuristics and associated processes, and will guide researchers and practitioners in advancements and use of such heuristics, and ultimately, provide formalized foundations to design science.

por.por_cntn:
Heuristics are rules of thumb that embody engineering experience. When used appropriately, they save engineering time and effort without sacrificing the quality of the system being engineered. The objective of this award was to enhance the scientific understanding of the use of approximations and heuristics in engineering design and systems engineering (EDSE). The research funded by this award has made significant contributions to the state of the art in design science. The research team defined more formally the concepts that are relevant to design heuristics, concluding that one should think of a heuristic as a combination of a context in which the heuristic is applicable, and a corresponding design action to be considered. A computational framework was developed, called the Design Decision Framing Model (DDFM), in which heuristics can be modeled computationally and compared.  

 

A number of human subjects studies were performed to better understand heuristics and their use in engineering design practice. A study with graduate level robotics design researchers allowed for the establishment of a heuristic extraction and categorization method. The research team worked with expert engineering designers, specifically NASA Jet Propulsion Laboratory’s (JPL) Architecture Team (A-Team), to develop a novel method for extracting heuristics from observations/interviews. Interviews and surveys were used to characterize gathered heuristics in terms of value (evolution, reliability, frequency of use), and find significant correlations between these attributes. Another study was completed with JPL involving a half-day workshop, in which participants collectively documented the planning heuristics they use to do early stage mission development.  The important outcomes of this work were the identification of benefits and drawbacks of different approaches to heuristic extraction research, using the JPL data as a case study. 

 

In terms of broader impacts of the research, there were significant contributions made to understanding how heuristics play a role in education and workforce development. A study with Siemens engineers was performed to learn how different representations of heuristics change their ability to abstract and apply the knowledge to a design problem, within the context of design for additive manufacturing and part redesign. This study was then extended by applying the procedure to novice engineering design students. The combined results from the expert and novice studies contributed to the understanding of how best to teach or train individuals using heuristic knowledge, depending on their level of expertise. The  contributions to the engineering design research community include a formalized method for extracting heuristics and their attributes from designers, with particular focus on origin, classification, and applicability context. While most of the past work on design heuristics has focused on ideation heuristics, this research has broadened this perspective and formalized design heuristics to encompass any guidance for choosing a design action based in a given design context, including through detailed design heuristics, system-level design heuristics, and planning heuristics. The major contributions include new insights into how best to present heuristics for their understanding and abstraction to new problems, how to characterize heuristics in terms of value, and different methods and their tradeoffs for extracting heuristics from designers/design output.
